posts.title: Researcher Spotlight: Oksana Lebedivna
posts.text: "My research centers on sound changes since Common Slavic and how they are reflected in one of the Slavic dialects which demonstrates archaic language features."

posts.title: The Library Adds Access to Central and East European Online Library (CEEOL)
posts.text: CEEOL is a leading provider of academic e-journals and e-books in the humanities and social sciences from and about Central and Eastern Europe.

posts.title: NYPL Acquires First Book of Poetry by Aleksis Rannit
posts.text: Aleksis/Aleksei Rannit was an Estonian poet, art critic, and librarian. He worked at the Library from 1956-1961 before becoming the curator of the Slavic and East European collections at Yale University Library where he remained for 20 years.

posts.title: Catherine II’s Altar Gospel Graces the Polonsky Exhibition of The New York Public Library’s Treasures
posts.text: The splendidly decorated Altar Gospel, prepared by command of Catherine the Great, Empress of Russia, was likely a benefaction to the Saint Alexander Nevsky Monastery in St. Petersburg.

posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight: Jill Martiniuk
posts.text: During her Short-Term Fellowship at the New York Public Library, Martiniuk conducted research for her latest project on the adaptation and appropriation of Slavic folklore in contemporary young adult and popular literature in the West.

posts.title: The Library Acquires a Collection of Russian Zines
posts.text: 22 Russian zines, most published within the last five years, have been added to our collections. They cover a wide spectrum of topics from politics, feminism, housing development, cats, and much more.

posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight: Robert W. Montgomery
posts.text: This profile is part of a series of interviews chronicling the experiences of researchers who use The New York Public Library's collections for the development of their work.

posts.title: Digitized Imperial Russian Newspapers Now Available via the Global Press Archive
posts.text: The Imperial Russian Newspapers collection comprises out-of-copyright newspapers spanning the eighteenth, nineteenth, and early twentieth centuries, up to the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution.

posts.title: Literaturnaia gazeta Archive Now Available at NYPL
posts.text: The first newspaper under this title was published between January 1, 1830 and June 30, 1831 by a literary group led by Russian poet and journalist Anton Antonovich Delvig and a world-famous Russian poet, playwright, and novelist Alexander Sergeyevich Pushkin.

posts.title: On the 230th Anniversary of the First European Constitution (1791)
posts.text: Poland has a long parliamentary and constitutional tradition. Here is a select list of publications which offer the text of major constitutions and works on them available through NYPL and partners.

posts.title: Literary Slavic New York
posts.text: In the second half of the nineteenth century, New York became a significant center of Slavic publishing activity, including both books and periodicals. Also, numerous writers and poets of Slavic background called New York their home or spent time in the city.

posts.title: The Hundredth Anniversary of the Treaty of Riga
posts.text: The treaty was signed between Poland on one side and Russian and Ukrainian Soviet republics on the other. It ended the Russo-Polish War of 1919–20 and established a new Polish border.

posts.title: Before Suffrage: Feminism in Slavic and East European Lands
posts.text: It was only beginning in 1917 that the process to introduce women's right to vote picked up momentum worldwide resulting in women's suffrage becoming a reality in an increasing amount of states, including Slavic and East European countries. Below are some books written in the late 19th and early 20th century (all digitized) which were published to raise an awareness and appreciation of women's contributions to society.

posts.title: Digitized Slavica: Zlatá Praha
posts.text: Zlatá Praha was a Czech illustrated magazine that was first published in 1864-1865 and later in 1884-1929. Almost all of its content has been digitized.

posts.title: Digitized Slavica: Uwagi Tygodniowe Warszawskie
posts.text: Uwagi tygodniowe warszawskie was the first Polish periodical fully dedicated to the subject of agricultural development. Only 52 weekly issues were published (1768-1769). The NYPL's copy carries the handwritten notes of the previous owner(s) and some parts of the text are underlined in red pencil.

posts.title: Научные электронные книги на русском языке теперь доступны в NYPL
posts.text: Нью-Йоркская публичная библиотека начала пилотный проект по приобретению научных электронных книг на русском языке.Подборка российских научных книг (история, политика и международные отношения, религия и философия, литературная критика и. т. д.), а также биографические и справочные издания будут добавляться каждый месяц на

posts.title: Scholarly E-Books in Russian Now Available
posts.text: We've begun a pilot project to acquire scholarly e-books in Russian on topics such as history, politics, international relations, religion and philosophy, biographies, literary criticism, and reference sources.

posts.title: N. Kymmel: An Early Supplier of Books from Russia
posts.text: N. Kymmel was a bookstore, a publishing house, and an antiquarian book dealer based in Riga (Russian Empire, later Latvia). The NYPL started purchasing books from it soon after establishing the Slavonic Division in 1899.

posts.title: Где получить доступ к электронным материалам на русском языке
posts.text: Помимо электронных книг на русском языке, Нью Йоркская Публичная Библиотека предлагает нашим читателям доступ к газетам, журналам и научно-периодическим изданиям в электронном формате.

posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight (WFH edition): Prof. Yasha Klots
posts.text: Like many of us, Klots' research routine has pivoted to materials he can access from his home office.

posts.title: Digitized Slavica: Magazin DP
posts.text: Magazin DP brought together designers, manufacturers, and distributors of applied arts and modern design to create affordable items of mass consumption for a wide range of people.

posts.title: The 19th Century Hand Colored Photographs of Moscow by J. Daziaro
posts.text: In honor of National Photography Month, let's learn about the history of this famed publishing house in Russia.

posts.title: How Were Immigrants Seen…A Hundred Years Ago?
posts.text: Explore the digitized New American Series, which was published in the United States just before Ellis Island was closed to mass immigration and tended to be sympathetic but critical in its approach to the immigrants.

posts.title: Digitized Slavica: Khudozhestvennyia sokrovishcha Rossii
posts.text: Khudozhestvennyia sokrovishcha Rossii [Artistic Treasures of Russia] is one of the best Russian periodicals on art from the beginning of the 20th century.

posts.title: Novoe Ruskoe Slovo Now Available in Digital Format
posts.text: The digital archive includes over 40,000 pages with full page-level digitization, complete original graphics, and keyword searchable text.

posts.title: PressReader Database: Your Window on the World
posts.text: You don't have to travel to keep up with news in other countries.

posts.title: Open House to Celebrate International Mother Language Day
posts.text: Come join us!

posts.title: Welcoming Recent Guests and Receiving Gifts at NYPL
posts.text: In recent weeks, NYPL has hosted a number of distinguished guests from Lithuania, Latvia, and Poland, and received generous gifts for our collections.

posts.title: Leopold Niemirowski's Contribution to the 1844-1845 East Siberian Expedition
posts.text: The illustrations that detail Ivan Dem'ianovich Bulychev's 1,000 km-expedition were created by a Polish political prisoner born to a noble family - a man largely forgotten by history until the 1990s.

posts.title: The Coronation of the Last Tsars
posts.text: With the recent debut of the docudrama "The Last Czars," we look at images from a rare presence in the NYPL collections: seven coronation albums of the tsars, the largest such collection outside of Russia.

posts.title: Primo Levi at 100: If This Is a Man
posts.text: In honor of 100 years since Primo Levi's birth, multilingual artists, teachers, and writers will read from "If This Is A Man," Wednesday, June 12 from noon to 8 PM at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building.

posts.title: Early Russian Interest in Walt Whitman’s Works
posts.text: Two hundred years after Walt Whitman's birth, a new NYPL exhibition at the New York Public Library examines many of the individuals, beliefs, and experiences that shaped Whitman’s work, and features Whitman's impact on foreign writers and literatures, including Russian authors.

posts.title: Hymn To Apollo: The Ancient World and the Ballets Russes
posts.text: Get dates, times, and details for this exhibition at NYU, which explores the role of dance in ancient culture, with some objects on view loaned by NYPL.

posts.title: Upcoming Slavic and East European Programs at the Library
posts.text: From poetry readings and a family celebration of Alexander Pushkin, to the screening of a famed film, join us for a series of East European-focused events throughout NYPL.

posts.title: Andy Warhol's Ethnicity and the Other Warhol Exhibition
posts.text: While Warhol fans lined up around the block for an exhibition at the Whitney, another Warhol-focused show at New York City's Ukrainian Museum included discussion about the artist's ethnic roots and background which, as he once summarized, he "prefer[red] to remain a mystery."

posts.title: Two New Exhibits Feature Artistic Contributions by East Europeans
posts.text: Two exhibitions at the NYPL Library for the Performing Arts highlight the work of artists of East European background: one a groundbreaking composer and technologist, the other a world-famous choreographer, dancer, and theater producer.

posts.title: 100 Years Club: Long-Lasting Business Periodicals at the NYPL
posts.text: The names, layouts, and designs change but the publications endure. Discover a select series of periodicals with at least a century of NYPL archives.

posts.title: Industries You May Not Have Heard Of
posts.text: At the Science, Industry and Business Library, our extensive collection of industry surveys goes beyond the expected (from Airlines to Textiles) to include industries you may not have heard of. How about The Happiness Industry?

posts.title: Guide to Business Resources For Creatives
posts.text: If you're looking to turn creative abilities into cash flow, here are lists of resources to provide some helpful expertise.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Part 9
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to have a portion of its older pre-1923 collections digitized.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Part 8
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to have a portion of its older pre-1923 collections digitized.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Pt. 7
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to digitize a portion of its older pre-1923 collections.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Pt. 6
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to digitize a portion of its pre-1923 collections.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Pt. 5
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to have a portion of its older pre-1923 collections digitized.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Pt. 4
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to have a portion of its older pre-1923 collections digitized.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Pt. 3
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to have a portion of its older pre-1923 collections digitized.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Pt. 2
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to have a portion of its older pre-1923 collections digitized.

posts.title: Digitized Historical Business Periodicals from the Library's Collection: Pt. 1
posts.text: Responding to current information delivery practices, the Library has been working with Google to have a portion of its older pre-1923 collections digitized.

posts.title: 120 Years of Indian Motorcycles
posts.text: Learn about the historical and modern motorcycles in numerous trade publications, available at the Science, Industry and Business Library.

posts.title: 19th Century Innovations from The Mechanics' Magazine
posts.text: The New York Public Library holds one of the most comprehensive collections of British patents dating back to the 17th century (30,000+ volumes!). Publications such as The Mechanics Magazine, founded by a Scottish patent agent, described many patented inventions.

posts.title: Celebrating SIBL: A Bibliography of Works About the "Miracle on Madison Avenue"
posts.text: Since the Science, Industry and Business Library opened on May 2, 1996—at the time considered a "Miracle on Madison Avenue" by The New York Times—its stunning setting, wide range of resources and services, and great array of offerings have attracted the attention of pundits, industry experts, and information professionals.

posts.title: October 27 in Science, Industry and Business History
Medicare Counseling at SIBL
posts.text: Medicare Counseling is here at the Library: We invite you to visit a Medicare counselor at the Science, Industry and Business Library.

posts.title: A Decade of Exhibits at the Science, Industry and Business Library: 1999-2009
posts.text: This October, for the first time in seven years, SIBL will once again host an exhibition in Healy Hall, No Home to Go To, from the Balzekas Museum in Chicago. Below is the list of past exhibitions held at the Science, Industry and Business Library.

posts.title: Getting Funded: SIBL's First Business Financing Fair Is a Success
posts.text: The Business Financing Fair had representatives from both traditional and alternative sources of funding who answered questions from start-ups and established businesses.

posts.title: 20 Years of Books Researched at the Science, Industry and Business Library
posts.text: As SIBL prepares to mark the twentieth anniversary of its opening on May 2, 1996, one sure way to illustrate the depth and diversity of its rich research collections is the following selective list of book publications whose authors credit SIBL resources—bibliographic and human—in their acknowledgements.

posts.title: We'll Come to You: A Roundup of 2015 Outreach at SIBL
posts.text: Over the years, SIBL has partnered with 100+ tri-state government agencies, NGOs, not for profits, schools, proprietary institutes, professional associations, and colleges. Shouldn't yours be next?

posts.title: Matching Patrons with Expert Practitioners: SIBL's Year in Programs and Classes
posts.text: Last year the Business Library offered 320+ sessions, repeating frequently those most in demand. Look for these and more in the year ahead.

posts.title: Bed, Bath and Flying Machines: Highlights from SIBL's Public Domain Collection
posts.text: There are 2,000 images from the Science, Industry and Business collection in the recent public domain release. Here is some of what you can find.

posts.title: Back in the U.S.S.R.: The Color Red in Early Advertising
posts.text: How and why does red make us want to buy?

posts.title: Alice in Other Wonderlands
posts.text: With everything that has been written about Alice in Wonderland, where do we start? Perhaps with a little help from Lewis Carroll himself.

posts.title: New York StartUp! 2015 Enters Its Final Stage
posts.text: New York StartUP! Business Plan Competition  is offered annualy by the Science, Industry and Business Library of The New York Public Library in conjunction with its sponsor, Citi Foundation.

posts.title: The Early Proposed Railways for New York City, Part 2
posts.text: Beach Pneumatic Transit Company built 312 feet of tunnel under Broadway from Warren Street to Murray Street. It closed in 1873 and the tunnel was used for a while as a shooting gallery, but even that did not pay, and for years the tunnel was neglected and the entrance was closed by an iron grating. Read more about the subway that could have been.

posts.title: How to Access Science Journals and Scholarship Online
posts.text: Looking for an encyclopedia of bugs you can get at home, or an idea for a chemistry experiment for a middle-schooler, or a citation to a research article in astrophysics or news of the latest trends in biotechnology? You can find most of this and more right at your local branch of The New York Public Library, or sometimes even at home.

posts.title: Free Succession Planning Workshop for Immigrant Entrepreneurs
posts.text: Are you an immigrant business owner? Start planning now for the future of your enterprises and your families.

posts.title: Financial Planning Day Draws A Crowd to SIBL... Again!
posts.text: The Science, Industry and Business Library's spring edition of Financial Planning Day for 2015 drew record crowds.

posts.title: Guide to Resources for Freelancers and Business Owners
posts.text: You may be setting out on your own as a freelancer or small business owner, but you don't have to do it alone. You have the world-class resources of The New York Public Library to help you every step of the way, from the planning stages all the way through to retirement.

posts.title: Frank Sinatra’s Flight to the Moon
posts.text: From his first job at the Rustic Cabin (earning $15 a week) to minting million dollar bills, tracing Sinatra's road to financial success.

posts.title: SIBL Salutes Its Volunteers
posts.text: Taking a moment to thank the expert practitioners who offer presentations in SIBL's lunch time and after-work seminar series, and provide  confidential one-on-one counseling and coaching to our patrons.

posts.title: Filing Taxes at SIBL
posts.text: Once again The Science, Industry and Business Library offers two Tax Assistance programs.  Fliers are available throughout SIBL and are reproduced here with a brief description of both programs. Please also consult Income Tax Information 2015 for tax filing help offered across the library.

posts.title: The Early Proposed Railways for New York City, Part 1
posts.text: "Everybody in New York wants rapid transit, but, strange to say, the moment that anybody sets to work with a definite plan for its realization, they are vigorously opposed and the work prevented." Looking at some of the early proposed (and sometimes partially built) railways for New York City for which the Science, Industry and Business Library has visual materials.

posts.title: The Business of Toy Guns
posts.text: Toys are a multi-billion dollar business. Toy guns are a small portion of that, but there are also laws restricting their sale.

posts.title: New Yearbook of the United Nations Launched
posts.text: The Yearbook of the United Nations—published by the Department of Public Information and available at the NYPL—stands as the authoritative reference work on the activities and concerns of the organization.

posts.title: Sesame Street: Not a Kiddie Business
posts.text: Sesame Street is beloved for its approach to childhood learning and development, but it is also an innovative business. SIBL has resources for you to learn more about the operations of the Sesame Workshop.

posts.title: SIBL Hosts 2014 NYC Small Business Technology Expo
posts.text: On a rainy November 6 SIBL hosted The 2nd annual NYC Small Business Technology Expo. This free event is part of a citywide initiative supported by the New York City Department of Small Business Services, Citi Community Development, and the The NYC Small Business Technology Coalition.

posts.title: SIBL Participates in New York Business Expo & Conference
posts.text: On October 30, 2014 SIBL's staff members once again participated in NYXPO at Javits Center. For nine years, this event has been the Northeast’s largest business to business trade show, conference and networking event for business owners and executives.

posts.title: 2014 Financial Planning Day at SIBL - A Big Success!
posts.text: On October 17, 2014 hundreds of people came to SIBL for classes, database presentations, counseling, coaching and to talk to Financial Fair Participants during our 2014 Financial Planning Day.

posts.title: Judge a Magazine by Its Cover: "Good Hardware"
posts.text: This magazine did not deal with hardware in today’s meaning of this word. In the October 1921 issue there were articles on sporting goods, electrical goods, sewing machines, auto accessories, window displays, and general pieces on how to sell merchandise.

posts.title: Fashion Advertising A Hundred Years Ago
posts.text: 1914 was a very eventful year in the world, and in magazine advertising.

posts.title: Digital Railroad Materials, Part 2
posts.text: Is there anybody out there who does not like trains? OK, perhaps more than a few people are fed up with their daily commute. Also, trains do sometimes fail us. It was very unfortunate that during the March Snowstorm of 1888 about seventy-five miles of the Long Island Railroad system was blockaded by the snow and that the street railroad system of Brooklyn became useless.

posts.title: William Curtis and "The Botanical Magazine, or, Flower-Garden Displayed"
posts.text: The world's longest running botanical magazine was (eventually) named after its founder William Curtis (1746–1799), who was an English botanist and entomologist. From 1771 to 1777 Curtis worked as demonstrator of plants and Praefectus Horti at the Chelsea Physic Garden, which was established a century earlier by the Worshipful Society of Apothecaries for its apprentices to study the medicinal qualities of plants.

posts.title: Digital Railroad Materials, Part 1
posts.text: The New York Public Library offers a tremendous amount of material in e-format. We have been purchasing e-books for years including e-text, e-audio, e-music, and e-video.  E-books include both fiction and non-fiction. Among the latter is Christian Wolmar's The Great Railroad Revolution.

posts.title: Will Bicycles Save the Human Race?
posts.text: Bicycles were first introduced in 19th century Europe and by now number approximately one billion worldwide, providing the principal means of transportation in many regions. In Bicycle: The History, David Herlihy noted the passions the introduction of bicycle aroused. Mark Twain (1835-1910) supposedly wrote: “Get a bicycle. You will not regret it—if you live.”

posts.title: Gustave Eiffel Beyond the "Useless and Monstrous" Tower
posts.text: Gustave Eiffel who was born 15 December 1832 in Dijon, Côte-d'Or, France was much more than “just” the creator of the Eiffel Tower. A man of many passions and accomplishments, Eiffel attended high school at Lycee Royal where he studied engineering, history and literature. He graduated with a degree in both science and humanities. He first studied at the École Polytechnique but later transferred to the École Centrale des Arts et Manufactures in Paris, graduating in 1855 with a diploma in …chemistry. He was interested in construction from an early age and a couple of years after
